summary: This is a court opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to suppress evidence obtained via a grand jury subpoena to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF). The evidence, including Maxwell's deposition transcripts from a prior civil defamation case, was covered by a protective order. The court rejects Maxwell's arguments that obtaining the evidence violated her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, her Fourth Amendment rights, or her due process rights, and denies her request for an evidentiary hearing.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, moving to suppress evidence (her deposition transcripts) obtained from a prior civil case via a grand jury subpoena to her opponent's law firm.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The United States District Judge for the Southern District of New York who authored this opinion and order denying Maxwell's motion to suppress.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual, alongside Maxwell, whom the plaintiff in the prior civil case accused of sexual abuse. The government's investigation into Epstein formally began in 2018.

persons.name: McMahon
persons.context: Then-Chief Judge who heard the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order in the civil case after the original judge passed away. She granted the application.

persons.name: Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who denied a similar government application in another case, applying the same legal standard but reaching a different conclusion on the facts.

connections.description: Maxwell is identified in the document as Epstein's 'head recruiter' of underage girls, and both were accused of sexual abuse by the plaintiff in the prior civil case.
BSF was the law firm that represented the plaintiff (Virginia Giuffre) who sued Maxwell for defamation in the prior civil litigation.

events.title: Defamation Lawsuit Filed
events.description: Virginia Giuffre sued Ghislaine Maxwell for defamation, alleging Maxwell called her a liar about claims of sexual abuse by Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Meeting between BSF Attorneys and AUSA
events.description: Three attorneys from Boies Schiller Flexner LLP met with an Assistant U.S. Attorney (AUSA) to provide information on possible criminal conduct, primarily focusing on Epstein and identifying Maxwell as his 'head recruiter'.

events.title: Formal Investigation Opened
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York formally opened its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein following Miami Herald articles about his conduct and prior plea deal.

events.title: First Ex Parte Hearing on Protective Order
events.description: Judge McMahon held the first ex parte hearing on the government's application to modify the protective order to allow BSF to comply with a grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Second Ex Parte Hearing and Order
events.description: Judge McMahon held a second ex parte hearing, questioned the government about prior contacts with BSF, and subsequently issued a sealed order and opinion granting the application to modify the protective order.

events.title: Court Denies Motion to Suppress
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issued this opinion and order denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to suppress evidence obtained via the grand jury subpoena to BSF.

keyFacts: The government obtained Ghislaine Maxwell's deposition transcripts from a prior civil defamation case via a grand jury subpoena served on the opposing law firm, Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF).
The court ruled Maxwell had no reasonable expectation of privacy in documents produced in civil litigation, even under a protective order, and thus no Fourth Amendment violation occurred.

The court ruled Maxwell's Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination was not violated because she voluntarily testified in the civil depositions and could have invoked the privilege but did not.

The court rejected Maxwell's due process claim, finding she failed to make a substantial showing that the government deliberately misled the court or that the alleged omission was necessary to the judge's decision to modify the protective order.
Much of the evidence obtained, including the bulk of Maxwell's deposition transcripts, has since been unsealed and made public by court order in the civil case.
